block.p: Re ''Waiting for Their Moment in the Worst Place on Earth to Be a Woman'':
Re ''Waiting for Their Moment in the Worst Place on Earth to Be a Woman'':

I write this with hands still shaking from reading Helene Cooper's Nov. 16 Editorial Observer highlighting the plight of women in Africa. I felt as if I had been swept up and taken to these places she writes about.
I could smell the horror and the poverty and the injustice, but Ms. Cooper did not hide the exultant truth either.

The knowledge she shared with us of the radiant courage -- the raw guts really -- and the humble dignity of the women who haunt her made my heart soar, though I also know shame as I think of my largely superficial life here in America.

If only every American had the chance to walk through the villages of Africa, we might not be able so easily to ignore the suffering of that continent, and our own lives here at home might take on a deeper, richer meaning.
Jana Frazier McLaughlin Grantsville, Utah, Nov. 16, 2005
